Situation1: They casually answer a mentee’s occasional questions during breaks.
Expectation2: Conduct daily prayers and religious services for the community
Situation2: Should attend the main weekly service that most of the community attends.
Story: I sat in the quiet corner of the community hall, sipping tea, when Daniel, my eager mentee, approached with a notebook in hand. He had a question about his career path, and I could see the hope in his eyes. As his mentor, I felt the familiar pull to share my experience, to guide him through his uncertainty. We began talking, and soon, our conversation deepened, stretching beyond the usual break-time chat. I glanced at my watch and felt a jolt—today was the main weekly service, the one I, as the priest, was expected to lead. The congregation would be gathering soon, waiting for me to open the prayers, to offer them comfort and guidance. My heart pounded as Daniel’s questions grew more urgent, his trust in me palpable. Yet, I could almost hear the distant hum of the community assembling, their faith resting on my presence. Torn between the immediate needs of my mentee and the spiritual expectations of my congregation, I felt the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding my full attention, each unwilling to wait.
